xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: The National Research Council of Thailand, the Royal Forest Department of Thailand, and the Economic-Planning Unit (former Socio-Economic Research Unit) of Malaysia kindly permitted MM to conduct part of the project. MM is grateful to H.-S. Yong for his continuous encouragements to conduct research in Malaysia, to K. Araya, T. Chanard, T. Hikida, the late J. Nabitabhata, H. Ota, and D.-Q. Rao for ield companionship, and A. Ohler for providing tissue samples. We also thank two anonymous reviewers for improving the manuscript. Part of this study was supported by grants from Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia (UKM-OUP-PI-26-116/2011) to NA and TORAY grant (MTSF1019-2007A) to DB. Field trips by MM were made possible by aid from The Monbusho through the Japanese Society for the Promotion of Sciences (JSPS: Field Research, Nos. 01041051, 04041068, 06041066, 08041144, and 20405013), Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia (UKM-OUP-PLW-14-59/2008), and TJTTP-OECF

affiliation.address-part: Gd. Widyasatwaloka, Jl. Raya Jakarta Bogor km 46

head.citation-title: Mitochondrial phylogeny of Leptolalax from Malay Peninsula and Leptobrachella (Anura, Megophryidae)
head.abstracts: © 2017 by The Herpetological Society of Japan.Phylogenetic relationships within the genus Leptolalax have been insuiciently resolved, while the relationships of a related genus Leptobrachella with other genera are totally unknown. In order to improve these situations, we assessed the phylogenetic relationships among 19 species of Leptolalax and four species of Leptobrachella based on 2067-2527 bp sequences of the mitochondrial 12S and 16S rRNA genes using maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference methods. Leptolalax and Leptobrachella formed a clade, in which each of the Bornean Leptolalax, continental Leptolalax, and Leptobrachella formed a clade with unresolved relationships. Within the continental clade, the species from the Malay Peninsula formed a sister clade to the clade of the remaining regions. The species from southern Thailand formed a sister clade to the species from more northern regions. These results suggest conining the name Leptolalax to Bornean species, and reexamining the contents of the name Lalos currently recognized. Pointed digital tips unique to Leptobrachella might have arisen parallelly in ancestral Leptolalax as in Leptobrachium. Absence of species common to both Borneo and the neighboring continent in Leptolalax unlike in many other anuran genera occurring in Borneo, suggests a unique evolutional history of the genus.

grant-text.$: The National Research Council of Thailand, the Royal Forest Department of Thailand, and the Economic-Planning Unit (former Socio-Economic Research Unit) of Malaysia kindly permitted MM to conduct part of the project. MM is grateful to H.-S. Yong for his continuous encouragements to conduct research in Malaysia, to K. Araya, T. Chanard, T. Hikida, the late J. Nabitabhata, H. Ota, and D.-Q. Rao for ield companionship, and A. Ohler for providing tissue samples. We also thank two anonymous reviewers for improving the manuscript. Part of this study was supported by grants from Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia (UKM-OUP-PI-26-116/2011) to NA and TORAY grant (MTSF1019-2007A) to DB. Field trips by MM were made possible by aid from The Monbusho through the Japanese Society for the Promotion of Sciences (JSPS: Field Research, Nos. 01041051, 04041068, 06041066, 08041144, and 20405013), Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia (UKM-OUP-PLW-14-59/2008), and TJTTP-OECF

coredata.dc:description: Phylogenetic relationships within the genus Leptolalax have been insuiciently resolved, while the relationships of a related genus Leptobrachella with other genera are totally unknown. In order to improve these situations, we assessed the phylogenetic relationships among 19 species of Leptolalax and four species of Leptobrachella based on 2067-2527 bp sequences of the mitochondrial 12S and 16S rRNA genes using maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference methods. Leptolalax and Leptobrachella formed a clade, in which each of the Bornean Leptolalax, continental Leptolalax, and Leptobrachella formed a clade with unresolved relationships. Within the continental clade, the species from the Malay Peninsula formed a sister clade to the clade of the remaining regions. The species from southern Thailand formed a sister clade to the species from more northern regions. These results suggest conining the name Leptolalax to Bornean species, and reexamining the contents of the name Lalos currently recognized. Pointed digital tips unique to Leptobrachella might have arisen parallelly in ancestral Leptolalax as in Leptobrachium. Absence of species common to both Borneo and the neighboring continent in Leptolalax unlike in many other anuran genera occurring in Borneo, suggests a unique evolutional history of the genus.
coredata.dc:title: Mitochondrial phylogeny of Leptolalax from Malay Peninsula and Leptobrachella (Anura, Megophryidae)
